name: Deforestation loss due to land use change
description:
Deforestation loss due to land use change is considered as the coversion of forest to other land use that has been likely being produced due to the presence of neraby commodity driven aggriculture, independently wether human induced or not.

This deforestation due to commodity-driven agriculture can be direct or indirect. Direct  impact would be land use change in order to create new arable land (i.e. cutting trees for pasture) whereas indirect would be deforestation to create new roads to accommodate better supply and transport.

In the methodology used for computing this indicator we are assuming just direct deforestation due to the change of forest to an especific commodity.

name: Carbon emissions due to land use change
description:
The different terrestrial ecosystems play an important role storing carbon on the below-ground plant organic matter and soil. Particularly forest, through growth of trees and the increase of soil carbon, contain a large part of the carbon stored on land.

Activities such us land use change or deforestation may affect carbon storage producing a disturbance of the carbon pools that may be released into the atmosphere.

Carbon emissions due to land use change would therefore be the realease of carbon into the atmosphere driven by the change from forest into a specific aggriculture commodity.

name: Biodiversity loss due to land use change
description:
Land use and land use change are complex issues affecting natural ecosystems.  Market forces can influence farmers’ decisions to expand into remaining natural ecosystems changing land uses producing direct or indirect preassures on biodiversity. Land use is, therefore, one of the main drivers of biodiversity loss.

The biodiversity loss due to land use change indicator estimates the regional species loss, displacement or reduction of species that would otherwise exist in the land if it wouldn"t be used for production of a certain commodity.

name: Unsustainable water use
description:
With the Unsustainable water use indicator we derive the total ammount of annual, crop-specific water use from the blue water rfootprint equirements.

The water footprint is an indicator of direct and indirect appropiation of freshwater resources. This term includes both consumptive water use and the water required to assimilate pollution. Advance frameworks consider both water performance in the direct operations as well as the indirect water footprint in order to fully understand how a certain business relates to water use efficiency and the exposure to risk.

The indicator developed provides incentives to improve water use efficiency through all sectors, highlighting those where water use efficiency is lagging behind.
